title: Extinction Rebellion protests Melbourne: Energy Australia climate rally
text:
Hundreds of climate protesters have gathered in Carlton Gardens ahead of widespread demonstrations that will shut Melbourne CBD roads tonight.

The Herald Sun understands the Extinction Rebellion protesters will block major city streets throughout peak hour, with Swanston, Bourke, Russell and Flinders streets to be affected.

The protest is part of the “Spring Rebellion”, which will see rallies run across the city throughout the week.

Retired clinical psychologist Jane Morton felt compelled to give her time and energy to the cause so there was a future for her children.

media_camera Extinction Rebellion activists have set up camp in Carlton Gardens. Picture: AAP Image/James Ross

media_camera Police patrol the gardens ahead of a week of disruption. Picture: AAP Image/James Ross

#ExtinctionRebelion “We’re sick and tired of inaction.” Protesters getting ready to head into the city for peak hour protests throughout the city. @theheraldsun pic.twitter.com/MqII0OZaWE — Tamsin Rose (@tamsinroses) October 7, 2019

“We are here to sound the alarm,” she said. “Scientists are trying to tell us that we have almost no time left before it’s too late.

“I’m here because it’s an emergency and I’m trying to protect a living planet for my kids.”

Activist leaders have warned people taking part that police might not “respect” their right to protest.

“Victoria Police are not always respectful of our right to protest,” group leader Liz Walsh said during an address to the group.

“The more people are here, the less able they are to trample on our rights. There will be probably a few arrests tonight.”

The swarm of protesters was also briefed by a legal expect on their rights around arrest and protest.

media_camera A driver looks on as protesters block a city intersection in Melbourne. Picture: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake

media_camera Protesters plan to cause a week of disruption. Picture: Jake Nowakowski

It comes after dozens of climate activists have EnergyAustralia’s Melbourne headquarters, creating a human barrier at the CBD building this afternoon.

Videos posted on social media show about 100 protesters waving flags and chanting slogans at 385 Bourke St.

Police can be seen inside as the activists block off the front of the building, banging on the glass windows in their rally against the energy giant.

The activists also brought traffic to a standstill in Melbourne’s CBD earlier with a demonstration that stopped motorists and public transport in its tracks.

Energy Australia owns the Yallourn power station, one of the most carbon polluting sites in Australia and they undermine #climateaction with #springst and in #auspol #extinctionRebellion closed access to city building where they have HQ on 33rd floor pic.twitter.com/UxgpnUGiI2 — John Englart EAM 🌏💦 (@takvera) October 7, 2019

media_camera Extinction Rebellion activists protesting as part of a “spring rebellion” across Melbourne this week. Picture: AAP Image/James Ross

media_camera Police face off with protesters rally at Energy Australia’s CBD offices. Picture: Jake Nowakowski

WEEK OF CBD DISRUPTION

Protesters warned of disruptions lasting over the next week in Melbourne’s CBD, with climate change activists expecting to be arrested.

And police have warned they’re ready to do just that, and are set to crack down on anyone trying to make trouble.

A small gathering of activists gathered outside Parliament House this morning for an all-day sit-in, with police patrolling the site.

The group is set to use bikes to block traffic and march in the nude over the coming days.

media_camera The march went down Bourke St mall. Picture: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake

media_camera An activist leads a protest march through the CBD. Picture: Jake Nowakowski

The Extinction Rebellion movement is planning a “spring rebellion” across Melbourne from Monday until Sunday.

Victoria Police Commander Tim Hansen says police will step in if there’s significant disorder, violence or if people’s safety is being put at risk.

“We’ve been taking considered legal advice and human rights advice over the last fortnight, and we have a fairly clear tactical plan (of) how we’re going to respond this week,” he told 3AW on Monday.

He said the Extinction Rebellion group has a right to peaceful protest, but members of the public have a right to freedom of movement.

“Not only do you have human rights, you also have human rights responsibilities here,” Commander Hansen warned protesters.

media_camera Protesters chant and shout slogans to raise awareness of climate change. Picture: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake

media_camera An disgruntled office worker looks on as protesters march through the CBD. Picture: Jake Nowakowski

media_camera Climate change protesters start their Spring St sit-in today. Picture: Aneeka Simonis

Based from Carlton Gardens, they plan to occupy the CBD on Tuesday and are prepared for peaceful arrests.

Dozens of protesters have begun setting up campsites.

A “swarm for survival” is planned for Wednesday, an “extinction rave” for Friday night and a “nudie parade” for Saturday.

This morning, a pink fishing boat with “climate emergency” painted on its side was pulled over by police near the camp.

Police intercepted the boat on Victoria St for a routine check of the trailer.

media_camera Extinction Rebellion activists block an intersection in Melbourne. Picture: James Ross

media_camera Police stopped this ute towing a boat in Melbourne. Picture: Aneeka Simonis

MORE: PROTEST BIGGER THAN THE GRAND FINAL

POLICE BRACE FOR DISRUPTIONS BY REBELS

Environment Victoria has extended its support to the group, saying their actions are understandable in such “desperate times”, in which political leaders appear unwilling to act on climate change.

“These are ordinary people pushed to do extraordinary things in a moment of crisis,” chief executive Jono La Nauze said in a statement.

“People from all walks of life are involved — builders, doctors, students, public servants and even former police officers.

Meanwhile, protests in Sydney have already turned ugly, with riot police dragging 20 protesters away from the city.

Chaotic scenes played out as elderly people and men in suits were arrested today.

Extinction Rebellion activists plan to shut down capital cities around the world this week — blocking roads, bridges, transport links and more — to demand urgent government action to address the climate and ecological emergency.

— With AAP
description: Major streets in Melbourne CBD will be shut down by climate activists during peak hour, with hundreds of protesters gathering ahead of the blockades. It comes after they created a human barrier at EnergyAustralias Bourke St headquarters today.
